title: Surrendering to His Will
devotional: Old Man Abernathy was known throughout the village for his stubbornness. Some said he was as immovable as the ancient oak that stood at the edge of his property. He refused to adopt the new farming techniques, clinging to the methods of his forefathers. He wouldn’t use the telephone, claiming letters were more personal. And most notably, he vehemently opposed the construction of the new community center, arguing it would disrupt the town's peaceful character. One summer, a terrible drought struck. The river that fed the Abernathy farm, and many others in the village, began to dwindle. The council, knowing Old Man Abernathy had the oldest and deepest well in the area, pleaded with him to share his water. He refused, citing tradition and personal property rights. As the days grew hotter and the crops withered, the villagers grew desperate. Finally, the village pastor, a kind and gentle soul, visited Abernathy. He didn't argue or accuse. He simply read a passage from Deuteronomy 15:7-8, which speaks of opening one's hand to the poor and needy. Abernathy remained silent, his face etched with a conflict only he could understand. The next morning, the villagers awoke to the sound of Abernathy's well pumping water into the communal irrigation system. He hadn't said a word, but his actions spoke volumes. He obeyed not out of pressure, but out of conviction. True obedience isn't about blind adherence; it’s about aligning our will with God's, even when it’s difficult. It requires a surrender of our own desires and a willingness to trust in His greater plan. Abernathy’s initial stance represented his will and comfort. It wasn't until he reflected on the word that he found the courage to surrender to obedience. It is not easy nor comfortable, but always right.
image_description: A weathered, but sturdy, water well stands in a verdant field, bathed in the warm glow of a summer sunset, implying abundance and provision.
insights: Abernathy's eventual act of sharing his water source highlights the transforming power of obedience to God's word. Deuteronomy 15:7-8 instructs, 'If there is a poor man among your brothers in any of the towns of the land that the Lord your God is giving you, do not be hardhearted or tightfisted toward your poor brother. Rather be openhanded and freely lend him whatever he needs.' This emphasizes the importance of compassion and generosity toward those in need, reflecting God's own character of love and provision.
prayer: Heavenly Father, I confess that I often struggle with obedience, especially when it conflicts with my own desires and plans. Help me to recognize Your will in all aspects of my life, and grant me the courage to follow Your guidance, even when it's difficult. Soften my heart to the needs of others, and empower me to be a vessel of Your love and compassion. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What areas of your life are you clinging to out of habit or stubbornness? How can you apply the principle of obedience to these areas? What specific steps can you take to align your will with God's will today?
